bibl.title: Letter from Jessie Daniel Ames to Philip Showalter Hench, July 12, 1942

div1.p: Jessie Ames answers Hench's questions concerning her husband's role in the yellow fever experiments. She suggests that Hench contact her sister-in-law for further information on Ames. She states that it is difficult for her to examine the past, but feels that she should as a duty to her children.

div1.head: Letter from Jessie Daniel Ames to Philip Showalter Hench, July 12, 1942

opener.dateline:
July 12, 1942 1288 Durand Drive NE
Atlanta
Georgia

div1.p:
This is written by me and before I continue, I want you to under-
stand that all errors are typographical. I am off to Virgina on busi-
ness this week and unless I inflict you with my own stenography it
will be some time before you can hear from me. And I judge your time
is short before you close your office up there.

1- You doubtless have the faver charts by now. I sent them
from Emory several days ago.

2-3-4- I have no copy of the reply from the editor of the
Journal of the A.M.A.- I have no carbons of any answers to
Dr. Berry's letters to my husband. I think Dr. Berry is dead.
He was a doctor in the Marine Hospital and Public Health
Service. I will write to-morrow to Washington and check on
him and his relatives. You may find something you want from
him or them and in the light of your short time, the least I
can do is to run down this line.

4- This question deserves a whole paragraph. I can explain and
I think interpret that sentence in the Berry letter. Dr.r
Dr. Berry was younger than my husband. He was Irish. He was
devoted to my husband and his devotion was quite personal.
He had Yellow Fever when he was stationed at Laredo with his
service and my husband in charge of Ft. McIntosh took care
of him. Dr. Berry thought that he owed his life to my husband.

He made a rash statement in his letter to the Editor of the
Journal and then called for corobberation. My husband was
temperamentally unable to tell Dr. Berry that he had gone
too far. So he merely stated that the fact was established
only in the newspapers and he knew nothing about even these
reports.

As far as my own knowledge goes, my husband never claimed that
he was an experimental case. At least he never did either to
me privately or in my presence to anyone else. I think it
unreal to assume that he was one. According to the pamphlets
written by other people, my husband, after Dr. Lazear's death,
was the only doctor connected with the service who knew Yellow
Fever from the first symptoms. It also was established in the
same pamphlets that the chances of recoverery depended entire-
ly on early diagnosis and promt first treatment. It would have
been foolishness of the first order to allow this authority
to be one of the experimental cases. Especially since there
was no lack of material among private soldiers and natives.

Why my husband's case of fever was deliberately suppressed
I have already written to you my opinion. I think I have also
written you that he must have been careless in handling the
infected mosquitoes of which carelessness he was profession-
ally ashamed. You may recall that Mr. Lambert tells the story
of carrying my husband on a cot while he was sick with the
fever so that he could order the proper treatment of one of
the experimental cases. This is akwardly expressed but you know
what I am saying. This has never been interpretted by me as an
act of heroism on my husband's part so much as an act of expiation
for his carelessness which might have been the cause of another's
death.

I think you may safely mark off the claim by some one that my hus-
band was one of the experimental cases. It reflects on his pro-
fessional judgement and the good sense of Dr. Reed.

5- I have sent you ever single solitary map, chart and other data that
I have. Read my answer to question 9.
6 I think it must refer to the fever charts which you now have.

7 The reprints were not enclosed. I felt sure you had copies of every-
thing that has been printed on the Cuba story. I listed them to indicate
the sources from which I gathered the data for the record.
8 I have done so.

9 My husband's sister's name and Address are
Mrs. Will Morris, 515 Adams Street, New Orleans.

I will not appear indifferent and careless in helping you to gather
the material on my husband. In order to avoid this I must tell you
a little family history. My hsuband's sister, he had two but this one
was his favorite to whom he wrote regularly and sent everthing, was
never partial to me. I was years younger than my husband and not a few
years younger than this sister. I tried to get her to send on to my
daughter the papers which she had written that she had. It would be
more than useless for me to write to my sister-in-law for them. I
told my daughter to make her letter casual which she did and got the
reply that when my sister-in-law found the time she would send them.

She mentioned in the letter she wrote to my daughter that she had
papers “of your father written before he ever knew your mother”. For
all I know they may be nothing but cancelled checks but when you asked
for exact data on this period of my husband's life which I did not
have it occurred to me that may be there might be something in these
papers.

I suggest that you write to her yourself; that you send the reprint
of the Yellow Fever story; that you tell her what you are doing; that
you ask her for pictures, group and of my husband alone taken at this
time; that you ask about maps, of the infected district or any other
tho I think you would better ask just for maps made at that time in-
stead of designating what maps; that you do not mention me or that you
have secured any data of a personal or private nature, tho you probably
have already gathered that you would not do so if you really want re-
sults.

10 Wearing a mustachce, off and on and this is not meant to be funny, be-
gan when my husband was about sixteen years old. During our too brief
married life he shaved and grew another one exactly three times. It
was one of his small vanities, this proving that he could grow one faste
than nature ordinarily allowed.

11-I have sent to my cousin for the photostat of the Picayune of the s
story for which you ask. There is nothing to be had from Havana
I'll send the Picayune story as soon as it comes.

12- I do not have another copy. If you are not in a huryy for it, I can
slip it in during some leisure moments of my secretary. If you want
it right now I can have it sent out.

At first it was not specially easy for me to dig into the past
but it was a duty to my children to do so. Besides it was mighty lit-
tle for me to be doing in the light of your undertaking. Later it has
given me pleasure. Your method of asking for what you want in the one,
two, three manner has made the easy work of getting to you what you want
to know in the order you want it even tho some of your questions
reminded me of final examinations in which the professor asked a quest-
ion of ten words which took a thousand to answer. But I thought if
you wanted all I had to say I should not ration waords. I still have
plenty left.

One of the keenest pleasures in this whole job has been the revival
of the memories of my husband's genius for arousing undying loyalty
among his associates, with a few exceptions, and his amazing capaci-
ty for democratic behavior.

My son, or did I tell you, is a Lieutenant in the Medical Corps, USNR.
He is in Little Rock now but expects to be transferred soon. I hope
for his happiness he will be sent to sea soon. My older daughter be
gan her third and last year of interning on July 1st in Detroit. It
is her first experience so far north and she is not greatly impressed
so far. All three of my offspring are satisfactory persons.

I hope you will keep me informed of the progress you make in this
work and that you will let me know where your hospital will be. I
shall be eager to know whether or not my sister-in-law has anything
you need.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, Jessie Daniel Ames Box 485
Emory University
Georgia
